captions.text:
You might tend to assume that everyone sees
the world in pretty much the same way, within

the same sets of colors that we call visible
light, as if we were all coloring with the
same box of crayons.

But the truth is, how many colors you can
perceive actually depends on what you're working
with.

Our eyes are these amazing energy converters,
taking light energy and turning it into chemical

energy and transmitting it to our brains through
nerves. And within our retinas at the backs

of our eyes are receptor cells called cones
and rods.

Rods allow us to see in black and white and
grey, and they're still effective in dim light,

and most humans have more than one hundred
and twenty million of them. Cones on the other

hand are they eye's color receptors, we only
have six million of those, and they enable
us to see fine detail in well-lit conditions.

Most people have three types of cones: blue,
red and green, and each receptor is triggered

by different wavelengths of light. The brain
combines the signals from the three types

of receptors to produce what we perceive as
color. When you put all the various combinations

from these three receptors together, most
humans can see about one million colors. This
is called trichromacy.

Color-blindness usually occurs when a person
is missing one of those cone receptors - almost

always either red or green. This is called
dichromacy, and it reduces the ability to
distinguish between those two colors.

Interestingly, there are varying degrees of
color blindness. Dichromatics can see about

ten thousand colors, but humans with monochromacy,
who are missing two or all three types of

cones, only perceive about one hundred colors
- mostly shades of grey.

And because the genes that affect color vision
are on the X chromosome, disparities in color
vision often correspond with your sex.

Biological males only have one X chromosome,
so they're more likely to inherent color blindness

- about 8% of men have some form of it. But
biological females have two X chromosomes,

so for them to be affected they have to have
the color blindness trait on both of their

sex chromosomes. As a result, color blindness
in women is really rare, showing up less than
1% of the time.

But the X chromosome is also where scientists
have recently found a genetic mutation that
may be linked to a sort of technicolor superpower.

In 2010, British scientists identified the
first known Tetrachromat - a woman whose eyes

has a fourth type of cone that can register
shades between red and green - basically enabling

her to perceive at least one hundred million
colors.

This, too, seems to be a sex-linked trait,
and other studies have suggested that as many

3% of the world's women may have this ability,
in which case paint companies and crayon makers

are gonna have a lot of new names to come
up with.

Thank you for asking, especially to our Subbable
subscribers who keep these answers coming.

If you have a quick question, let us know
on facebook or twitter or in the comments

below, and don't forget to go to youtube.com/scishow
and subscribe.

title: How Many Colors Can We See?

comments.text:
My uncle is colour-blind. I found out when we were eating dinner once and 
he asked me to pass him the blue mustard bottle. It's interesting because 
he's an artist and his paintings are great, but I've noticed he never 
really paints with bright colours. The funny thing is, he didnt even know 
he was colour-blind until after he married my aunt and he accidentally 
painted a portrait of her where she had green skin. He's been much more 
careful to check the labels on his paint since then.﻿

comments.author: Ameng

comments.text:
Cones: The retinas colors receptors. They consist of three different cone 
receptors, red, green, and blue. Fact: As you saw in the video its shows an 
example of the visible light spectrum with red being on the lefthand side 
and blue on the righthand side. Now you might be saying, "Hey wait, purple 
is on the righthand side not blue, I think you are colorblind.", just to 
make sure there are no misunderstandings (which I am sure there will be) I 
am speaking about the primary colors. With red and blue on the opposite 
ends of the visible light spectrum, how do we see purple? Well purple or 
magenta is and imaginary color. Yep thats right suprised me aswell, if that 
didn't suprise you well it didn't. It has no wavelength so it is an 
illusion. Just like yellow with red and green mixed you will not 
differentiate the red and green colors, instead you will see yellow even 
though orange is in between red and green. Yellow is not a primary color in 
the visible light spectrum. It does have a wavelength because it is inside 
the visible light spectrum. Purple does not because it it created by the 
two primary colors on the ends of the visible light spectrum. But yellow 
and blue make green even though red and green make yellow... this is 
confusing.

Rods: The retinas 'motion' receptors, not night vision receptors. Some 
people use a thing called averted vision by using your eyes periferals 
which have the biggest density of rods to see far away objects more clearly 
and see motion better.

The Tapidus Lucidum (correct me if I am wrong on that one.: This is what 
animals like dogs have. This allows them to see in the dark because it 
captures protons in the retina and sends them back out. You can see this 
effect by using the flash mechanism on your phone and taking a picture of 
your, for example, dog. The animals eyes appear to be glowing right, this 
is the tapidus lucidum at work. I AM NOT ENTIRELY SURE THAT THIS WILL WORK 
FOR EVERYONE AND I DO NOT TAKE ANY RESPONSIBILITY FOR ANY HARM DONE TO ANY 
ANIMALS OR PEOPLE, DO THIS AT YOUR OWN RISK.

If I am wrong about anything I will accept corrections in the reply 
section.﻿

The X-linked form of colorblindness (there are others) is also called 
deuteranopia or Daltonisn after chemist John Dalton, who described his own 
condition in a paper in 1798. Can you imagine a chemist of that era being 
colorblind? Did he have to call an assistant to tell him what happened to a 
solution when he added a reagent? A dude worthy of one of your bios.﻿

comments.author: Juan Pablo Mina

comments.text:
Title: How many colors can we see. This was answers for dichromatic, and 
monochromatic and tetrachomatic people, yet not for the 9 out of 10 of us 
who are trichromatic, except that it's likely between 10,000 and 100 
million. Since the ratio per rod type seems to be a factor of 100, I can 
guess it's a million, but I wish the title would match the content, and the 
answers would be given.﻿

comments.author: Igmu Tanka Luta

comments.text:
This video was well presented but the information was simplified to the 
point of risking being misleading as to coluor blindness. For those 
interested, http://www.colourblindawareness.org/

For those with normal colour vision that wonder what the world looks like 
to people with colour blindness here are two sites that attempt to show you.
(by using images) 
http://prometheus.med.utah.edu/~bwjones/2013/12/color-blindness-what-does-it-look-like/
(by using color palette) http://www.iamcal.com/toys/colors/

And for fun, the "Colour Blindness Simulator" takes your images (1000 x 
1000 pixels & 100 KB filesize JPEG) and changes them to appear as they 
would to someone with a variety of colour blindness.
http://www.etre.com/tools/colourblindsimulator/

comments.author: Amanda Engelshteyn

comments.text:
Minor correction.  You said that Females are less likely to inherit the 
gene for colorblindness, but the opposite is actually true.  Because they 
have two X chromosomes, they have twice as many sources to receive the gene 
from.  They are much less likely (1/4 as likely) to exhibit that trait 
because the other chromosome could cover for the "bad" one and 
colorblindness is a recessive trait.﻿
